TRIZ_Principles.Explanation: Divide an object or system into independent parts to simplify, improve efficiency, or make it more flexible.
Remove a troublesome or unnecessary component from a system.
Modify the system or object locally to adapt to specific conditions or requirements.
Replace a symmetrical system with an asymmetrical one to improve efficiency or functionality.
Combine multiple systems, objects, or operations into a unified whole to simplify and improve performance.
Use a single system or component to perform multiple functions.
Place one object inside another, like nested dolls, to save space or improve performance.
Use balancing weights or forces to counteract undesired effects of gravity or other forces.
Take preventive measures in advance to counteract potential problems.
Perform an action beforehand to simplify or prepare the system for the main operation.
Prepare a backup system or use redundancy to mitigate potential issues.
Avoid the need to raise or lower objects by using systems that balance potential energy levels.
Invert the system or operation, such as turning it upside down, to solve a problem more effectively.
Use rounded shapes or smooth transitions to improve efficiency and reduce stress points.
Make the system or object adaptable or movable to improve functionality or efficiency.
Perform the operation partially or excessively to achieve the desired result.
Move a system to a different spatial dimension to simplify or improve its operation.
Use vibrations or oscillations to enhance the operation or functionality of a system.
Use periodic motion or interruptions to improve the system or reduce resource usage.
Ensure the operation runs continuously without unnecessary stops or delays.
Perform an operation quickly or skip certain steps to enhance efficiency.
Use a harmful effect or a problem as an advantage or solution.
Introduce feedback loops to monitor and improve the system's performance dynamically.
Use an intermediary system or object to connect or facilitate between components.
Make a system capable of self-maintenance, self-repair, or self-operation.
Use a replica or imitation of the system instead of the original for testing or operation.
Use inexpensive, disposable objects for temporary operations or as prototypes.
Replace mechanical components with alternative systems like electronics, optics, or chemicals.
Use fluids or gases to achieve desired operations instead of mechanical systems.
Use flexible materials to adapt to changing conditions or improve performance.
Use materials with porosity for improved functionality, such as filtering or absorption.
Change the color or appearance of the system to convey information or enhance functionality.
Ensure uniformity or consistency within the system to improve reliability.
Remove or discard unnecessary parts and recycle useful ones to optimize the system.
Adjust system parameters such as temperature, pressure, or speed to improve performance.
Use phase transitions, such as solid-to-liquid or liquid-to-gas, to achieve desired results.
Use thermal expansion or contraction to simplify or enhance a system.
Introduce oxygen or other reactive agents to improve efficiency or performance.
Use an inert environment to protect sensitive systems or components.
Combine materials with different properties to achieve superior performance.
